facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 130 of 1970 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 130 of 1970. Appeal by Special leave from the Judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Judgment and Order dated 6th July 1970 of Rajasthan High Court at Jodhpur in B. Criminal Appeal No. 342 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 6th July, 1970 of the Rajasthan High Court at Jodhpur in B. Criminal Appeal No. 342 of 1967. Nuruddin Ahmad and Sobhagmal Jain, for the appellant Maya Rao, for the respondent.

facts.text: Appellant convicted under section 5(1)(d) read with section 2 of Prevention of Corruption Act 1947 and section 161 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: the question for companysideration is whether the companycurrent finding of guilt recorded by the learned Special Judge, Jaipur and the High Court of Rajasthan is in accordance with law and the evidence in the case. The appellant has been companyvicted under section 5 1   d  read with section s  2  of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 as also under section 161 of the Penal Code.

facts.text: Appellant sentenced to undergo rigorous imprisonment for one year and fine of Rs. 100/- on each count.

anchor.surface_text: He has been sentenced the undergo rigorous imprisonment for one year and to pay a fine of Rs. 100/- on each companynt.

facts.text: Complainant Umashanker is a cleaner in the Loco Shed, Kotah.

anchor.surface_text: The companyplainant Umashanker is a cleaner in the Loco Shed, Kotah. The appellant was working at the material time, as a clerk in the office of the Loco Foreman, Western Railway, Kotah, one of his duties being to process applications made by a certain class of employees for advances from the Provident Fund Account.

facts.text: Appellant was working as clerk in office of Loco Foreman, Western Railway, Kotah, duty to process PF advance applications.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was working at the material time, as a clerk in the office of the Loco Foreman, Western Railway, Kotah, one of his duties being to process applications made by a certain class of employees for advances from the Provident Fund Account. On April 8, 1966, the companyplainant presented an application to the appellant asking for an advance of Rs. 1501- from his Provident Fund Account.

facts.text: On April 8, 1966, complainant presented application to appellant for Rs. 150/- PF advance.

anchor.surface_text: On April 8, 1966, the companyplainant presented an application to the appellant asking for an advance of Rs. 1501- from his Provident Fund Account. It is alleged that the appellant refused to accept the application unless the companyplainant agreed to pay to him a gratification of Rs. 151-.

facts.text: Appellant refused application unless complainant paid Rs. 15/- gratification.

anchor.surface_text: It is alleged that the appellant refused to accept the application unless the companyplainant agreed to pay to him a gratification of Rs. 151-. On April 10, the companyplainant approached a Vigilance Officer Srinath Sharan Srivastava, and lodged a companyplaint before him that the appellant was demanding a bribe.

facts.text: On April 10, complainant approached Vigilance Officer Srinath Sharan Srivastava and lodged complaint of bribe demand.

anchor.surface_text: On April 10, the companyplainant approached a Vigilance Officer Srinath Sharan Srivastava, and lodged a companyplaint before him that the appellant was demanding a bribe. On the 12th the Vigilance Officer took the companyplainant to the office of the Special Police Establishment, Jaipur where Inspector Ajmera asked the companyplainant to make one more attempt to present the application to the appellant.

facts.text: On April 12, Vigilance Officer took complainant to Special Police Establishment, Jaipur; Inspector Ajmera instructed to attempt again.

anchor.surface_text: On the 12th the Vigilance Officer took the companyplainant to the office of the Special Police Establishment, Jaipur where Inspector Ajmera asked the companyplainant to make one more attempt to present the application to the appellant. Accordingly, the companyplainant resubmitted his application on the 13th when the appellant is alleged to have renewed his demand for a bribe.

facts.text: On April 13, complainant resubmitted application; appellant renewed demand for bribe.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, the companyplainant resubmitted his application on the 13th when the appellant is alleged to have renewed his demand for a bribe. A trap was thereafter laid and it is alleged that the appellant accepted from the companyplainant a sum of Rs. 151- on the evening of the 13th at Meghraj Hotel.

facts.text: Appellant accepted Rs. 15/- from complainant on evening of April 13 at Meghraj Hotel; notes Rs.10 and 5 treated with sodium carbonate powder; witnessed by Jagdish Prasad Tiwari and Bhagwandas Makhija.

anchor.surface_text: A trap was thereafter laid and it is alleged that the appellant accepted from the companyplainant a sum of Rs. 151- on the evening of the 13th at Meghraj Hotel. The two currency numberes of Rs. 10/- and 51- were treated with sodium carbonate powder and the payment is alleged to have been witnessed by the motbirs Jagdish Prasad Tiwari and Bhagwandas Makhija.

facts.text: Appellant admitted receipt of Rs. 15/- but contended it was part payment of Rs. 30/- loan advanced to complainant on November 1, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant admitted the receipt of the amount but companytended that the amount was paid to him by the companyplainant in part payment of a loan of Rs. 30/- which had been advanced by him to the companyplainant on November 1, 1965. He stated that the companyplainant had number presented to him any application at all on April 8 and on the 13th the appli- cation was presented number to him but to the Head-clerk.

facts.text: Appellant claimed no application presented to him on April 8; on April 13 presented to Head-clerk, processed normally and forwarded after Loco Foreman recommendation.

anchor.surface_text: He stated that the companyplainant had number presented to him any application at all on April 8 and on the 13th the appli- cation was presented number to him but to the Head-clerk. According to him the application of the 13th was processed by him in the ordinary companyrse and on the loan being recommended by the Loco Forman. the application was duly forwarded to the dispatch clerk for obtaining the sanction of the Divisional Superintendents Office.

facts.text: Evidence of PW4 Umashanker, PW5 Jagdish Prasad, PW6 Bhagwandas Makhija proves appellant accepted money from complainant.

anchor.surface_text: On the central issue whether the sum of Rs. 15/- had passed hands from the companyplainant to the appellant, we have the admission of the appellant himself but quite apart from that admission, there is clear and companyvincing evidence to show that the appellant had accepted the money from the companyplainant. The evidence of the companyplainant Umashanker  P. W. 4 , Jagdish Prasad  P. W. 5  and Bhagwandas Makhija W. 6  leaves numberdoubt on this point.

facts.text: Appellant in indigent circumstances on November 1, 1965 per monthly account Ex. D-11: September 1965 expenses exceeded income, sold silver; October overspent >Rs.100; November took Rs.80 loan from Railway Fund, sold wheat.

anchor.surface_text: A companyy of his monthly account  Ex. D- 11  produced by the appellant shows that on November 1, 1965, when the loan is alleged to have been given, the appellant was himself in indigent circumstances. In September, 1965, his expenses exceeded his income for which he had to sell some silver lying in the house in October, he overstepped his income by more than Rs. 100/- and in the crucial month of November he had to take a loan of Rs. 80/- from the Railway Fund and to sell some wheat lying in the house in order to meet his expenses.

facts.text: Debit entry of Rs.30/- in name of complainant in appellant's account inserted after scoring off another writing.

anchor.surface_text: The debit entry of Rs. 30/- in the name of the companyplainant was, as held by the High Court, evidently inserted after scoring off a writing against a sum of Rs. 30/-.

facts.text: When Inspector Ajmera disclosed identity, appellant became nervous and begged for mercy.

anchor.surface_text: When Inspector Ajmera disclosed his identity to the appellant and asked him to produce the money, he became nervous and begged for mercy.

facts.text: No particular intimacy between appellant and complainant; unlikely appellant gave loan without receipt or interest.

anchor.surface_text: Both the companyrts have held that the defence of the appellant is false and the preponderance of probabilities is in favour of the view that the amount was accepted by the appellant by way of bribe. ... There was numberparticular intimacy between the appellant and the companyplainant and it is number likely that the appellant would give a loan to the companyplainant, without a receipt and without interest.

facts.text: Complainant bore no enmity with appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The companyplainant bore numberenmity with the appellant and assuming, as companytended on behalf of the appellant, that there was some hostility between the appellant and the Head- clerk, Chandra Prakash Saxena, we see numberfoundation for the argument that Saxena influenced the companyplainant into lodging a false case against the appellant.

facts.text: Special Judge and High Court held appellant's loan defense false.

anchor.surface_text: Both the companyrts have held that the defence of the appellant is false ... The learned Special Judge described the loan theory propounded by the appellant as false, while the High Court observed that the companyclusion is irresistible that the theory is an after-thought. We are in agreement with this finding.

facts.text: Supreme Court agrees with lower courts that defense is false and amount accepted as bribe.

anchor.surface_text: We are in agreement with this finding.
Appeal by Special leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 6th July, 1970 of the Rajasthan High Court at Jodhpur in B. Criminal Appeal No. 342 of 1967.
The appellant has been companyvicted under section 5 1   d  read with section s  2  of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 as also under section 161 of the Penal Code.

issues.text: whether the current finding of guilt recorded by the learned Special Judge, Jaipur and the High Court of Rajasthan is in accordance with law and the evidence in the case

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal by special leave the question for companysideration is whether the companycurrent finding of guilt recorded by the learned Special Judge, Jaipur and the High Court of Rajasthan is in accordance

issues.text: whether the sum of Rs. 15/- had passed hands from the complainant to the appellant

anchor.surface_text: On the central issue whether the sum of Rs. 15/- had passed hands from the companyplainant to the appellant, we have the admission of the appellant himself but quite apart from that admission, there is clear and companyvincing evidence to show that the appellant had accepted the money from the companyplainant.

issues.text: whether the presumption under section 4(1) of the Prevention of Corruption Act can be raised only if the prosecution establishes that the amount was paid otherwise than as legal remuneration

anchor.surface_text: But learned companynsel appearing on his behalf urges that the presumption under section 4 1  can be raised only if the prosecution establishes in the first instance that the amount was paid otherwise than as legal remuneration. This companytention is companytrary to the clear terms of section 4 1

issues.text: whether the appellant discharged the burden under section 4(1) of proving the contrary to the presumption that the gratification was accepted as motive or reward for an official act

anchor.surface_text: Section 4 1  of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947, provides to the extent material, that where in any trial of an offence punishable under section 161 of the Penal Code or under section 5 2  of the Act, it is proved that an accused person has accepted any gratification  other than legal remuneration , it shall be presumed unless the companytrary is proved that he accepted that ratification as a motive or reward such as is mentioned in section 161, Penal Code.

arguments.claim: The Rs. 15/- received by the appellant was part payment of a loan of Rs. 30/- advanced by him to the complainant on November 1, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant admitted the receipt of the amount but contended that the amount was paid to him by the complainant in part payment of a loan of Rs. 30/- which had been advanced by him to the complainant on November 1, 1965.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: plainant to the appellant, we have the admission of the appellant himself but quite apart from that admission, there is clear and companyvincing evide

arguments.court_reasoning: Lower courts held false; SC agrees due to no intimacy, appellant's indigence per Ex. D-11, tampered debit entry, nervous reaction on trap, no receipt/interest, no complainant enmity.

arguments.claim: The complainant had not presented any application to the appellant on April 8, 1966, and on April 13 the application was presented not to him but to the Head-clerk, and was processed normally.

anchor.surface_text: He stated that the complainant had not presented to him any application at all on April 8 and on the 13th the appli- cation was presented not to him but to the Head-clerk. According to him the application of the 13th was processed by him in the ordinary course and on the loan being recommended by the Loco Foreman, the application was duly forwarded to the dispatch clerk for obtaining the sanction of the Divisional Superintendents Office.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ted with sodium carbonate powder and the payment is alleged to have been witnessed by the motbirs Jagdish Prasad Tiwari and Bhagwandas Makhija. The ap

arguments.court_reasoning: Clear evidence from PW4, PW5, PW6 proves acceptance; overall defense rejected.

arguments.claim: The presumption under section 4(1) PC Act arises only if prosecution first proves the amount was accepted otherwise than as legal remuneration.

anchor.surface_text: But learned counsel appearing on his behalf urges that the presumption under section 4 1  can be raised only if the prosecution establishes in the first instance that the amount was paid otherwise than as legal remuneration.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: himself but quite apart from that admission, there is clear and companyvincing evidence to show that the appellant had accepted the money from the co

arguments.court_reasoning: Contrary to clear terms of s.4(1); would render presumption illusory as prosecution need only prove acceptance and non-legal remuneration, then accused rebuts.

arguments.claim: Prosecution proved appellant accepted Rs. 15/- gratification other than legal remuneration, triggering presumption u/s 4(1) PC Act that it was motive/reward for official act u/s 161 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: Section 4 1  of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947, provides to the extent material, that where in any trial of an offence punishable under section 161 of the Penal Code or under section 5 2  of the Act, it is proved that an accused person has accepted any gratification  other than legal remuneration , it shall be presumed unless the contrary is proved that he accepted that gratification as a motive or reward such as is mentioned in section 161, Penal Code.

arguments.claim: Acceptance of Rs. 15/- proved by appellant's admission and convincing evidence of PW4 Umashanker, PW5 Jagdish Prasad, PW6 Bhagwandas Makhija.

anchor.surface_text: On the central issue whether the sum of Rs. 15/- had passed hands from the complainant to the appellant, we have the admission of the appellant himself but quite apart from that admission, there is clear and convincing evidence to show that the appellant had accepted the money from the complainant. The evidence of the complainant Umashanker  P. W. 4 , Jagdish Prasad  P. W. 5  and Bhagwandas Makhija W. 6  leaves no doubt on this point.

arguments.claim: Processing of provident fund advance application constitutes an official act for purpose of s.161 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The motive or reward mentioned in section 161 is inter alia, for doing or forbearing to do any official act. The prosecution having proved that the appellant had accepted the sum of Rs. 15/-, which clearly is not part of his legal remuneration, the presumption must be raised under section 4 1  of the Act that the appellant accepted the amount as a motive or reward for doing an official act.

arguments.claim: Burden under s.4(1) PC Act on accused to rebut presumption by preponderance of probabilities, not beyond reasonable doubt.

anchor.surface_text: As held in V. D. Jhingan vs. The State of Uttar Pradesh 1 , the accused can establish his case by preponderance of probabilities, that is to say, he need not prove his case beyond a reasonable doubt.

arguments.claim: Appellant's loan defense is false; preponderance favors bribe acceptance.

anchor.surface_text: Both the courts have held that the defence of the appellant is false and the preponderance of probabilities is in favour of the view that the amount was accepted by the appellant by way of bribe. The learned Special Judge described the loan theory propounded by the appellant as false, while the High Court observed that the conclusion is irresistible that the theory is an after-thought. We are in agreement with this finding.

arguments.claim: Unlikely appellant lent money without receipt/interest given no particular intimacy with complainant.

anchor.surface_text: There was no particular intimacy between the appellant and the complainant and it is not likely that the appellant would give a loan to the complainant, without a receipt and without interest.

arguments.claim: Appellant was indigent on Nov 1, 1965 per his own Ex. D-11, unlikely lender.

anchor.surface_text: A copy of his monthly account  Ex. D- 11  produced by the appellant shows that on November 1, 1965, when the loan is alleged to have been given, the appellant was himself in indigent circumstances. In September, 1965, his expenses exceeded his income for which he had to sell some silver lying in the house in October, he overstepped his income by more than Rs. 100/- and in the crucial month of November he had to take a loan of Rs. 80/- from the Railway Fund and to sell some wheat lying in the house in order to meet his expenses.

arguments.claim: Debit entry of Rs.30/- in appellant's account for complainant was tampered (inserted after scoring off).

anchor.surface_text: The debit entry of Rs. 30/- in the name of the complainant was, as held by the High Court, evidently inserted after scoring off a writing against a sum of Rs. 30/-.

arguments.claim: Appellant nervous and begged mercy when trap disclosed, inconsistent with creditor position.

anchor.surface_text: When Inspector Ajmera disclosed his identity to the appellant and asked him to produce the money, he became nervous and begged for mercy. He could not have forgotten that he was a creditor of the complainant in the sum of Rs. 30/- and that the amount was received by him in part payment of that loan.

arguments.claim: No enmity between complainant and appellant; no basis for false case influenced by Head-clerk hostility.

anchor.surface_text: The complainant bore no enmity with the appellant and assuming, as contended on behalf of the appellant, that there was some hostility between the appellant and the Head- clerk, Chandra Prakash Saxena, we see no foundation for the argument that Saxena influenced the complainant into lodging a false case against the appellant.

arguments.claim: Appellant failed to discharge burden under s.4(1) PC Act to prove contrary to presumption.

anchor.surface_text: As the appellant has failed to discharge his burden, the order of conviction and sentence must be confirmed.

holdings.text: The concurrent finding of guilt recorded by the learned Special Judge, Jaipur and the High Court of Rajasthan is in accordance with law and the evidence in the case.

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal by special leave the question for consideration is whether the concurrent finding of guilt recorded by the learned Special Judge, Jaipur and the High Court of Rajasthan is in accordance

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant failed to rebut presumption under s.4(1) PC Act; defense rejected based on evidence including indigence, tampered records, conduct, lack of intimacy/enmity.

holdings.text: The sum of Rs. 15/- passed from the complainant to the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: On the central issue whether the sum of Rs. 15/- had passed hands from the complainant to the appellant, we have the admission of the appellant himself but quite apart from that admission, there is clear and convincing evidence to show that the appellant had accepted the money from the complainant. The evidence of the complainant Umashanker (P. W. 4), Jagdish Prasad (P. W. 5) and Bhagwandas Makhija (W. 6) leaves no doubt on this point.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant's admission plus credible testimony of PW4, PW5, PW6 proves acceptance beyond doubt.

holdings.text: The presumption under section 4(1) PC Act arises upon proof of acceptance of any gratification other than legal remuneration; prosecution need not first establish it was not legal remuneration beyond triggering presumption.

anchor.surface_text: But learned counsel appearing on his behalf urges that the presumption under section 4(1) can be raised only if the prosecution establishes in the first instance that the amount was paid otherwise than as legal remuneration. This contention is contrary to the clear terms of section 4(1) and would render illusory the presumption arising under the section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clear textual reading of s.4(1); requiring prosecution to prove non-remuneration as bribe would negate presumption purpose.

holdings.text: Prosecution proved acceptance of Rs.15/- gratification other than legal remuneration, raising presumption under s.4(1) PC Act that it was motive or reward for official act under s.161 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: Section 4(1) of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947, provides to the extent material, that where in any trial of an offence punishable under section 161 of the Penal Code or under section 5(2) of the Act, it is proved that an accused person has accepted any gratification (other than legal remuneration), it shall be presumed unless the contrary is proved that he accepted that gratification as a motive or reward such as is mentioned in section 161, Penal Code. The motive or reward mentioned in section 161 is inter alia, for doing or forbearing to do any official act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Acceptance proved; amount not legal remuneration; processing PF advance is official act.

holdings.text: Appellant failed to discharge burden under s.4(1) PC Act of proving contrary to presumption by preponderance of probabilities.

anchor.surface_text: Both the courts have held that the defence of the appellant is false and the preponderance of probabilities is in favour of the view that the amount was accepted by the appellant by way of bribe. ... As the appellant has failed to discharge his burden, the order of conviction and sentence must be confirmed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Defense loan story false per lower courts (agreed by SC); supported by no intimacy, appellant's indigence (Ex.D-11), tampered entry, nervous reaction, no enmity/motive for false case; standard is preponderance not beyond doubt (V.D. Jhingan precedent).

holdings.text: Appellant's defence that Rs.15/- was part-payment of prior loan is false; preponderance favors bribe.

anchor.surface_text: We are in agreement with this finding.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with Special Judge (false theory) and High Court (after-thought); evidentiary improbabilities.

precedents.citation: V. D. Jhingan vs. The State of Uttar Pradesh 1

anchor.surface_text: As held in V. D. Jhingan vs. The State of Uttar Pradesh 1 , the accused can establish his case by preponderance of probabilities, that is to say, he need number prove his case beyond a reasonable doubt. A.I.R. 1966 S.C. 1762.

precedents.cited_proposition: the accused can establish his case by preponderance of probabilities, that is to say, he need number prove his case beyond a reasonable doubt

outcome.relief_summary: Order of conviction and sentence confirmed; appeal dismissed implicitly by upholding lower courts' findings

anchor.surface_text: On the central issue whether the sum of Rs. 15/- had passed hands from the complainant to the appellant, we have the admission of the appellant himself but quite apart from that admission, there is clear and convincing evidence to show that the appellant had accepted the money from the complainant. The evidence of the complainant Umashanker (P. W. 4), Jagdish Prasad (P. W. 5) and Bhagwandas Makhija (W. 6) leaves no doubt on this point.
As the appellant has failed to discharge his burden, the order of companyviction and sentence must be companyfirmed.

anchor.surface_text: But learned counsel appearing on his behalf urges that the presumption under section 4(1) can be raised only if the prosecution establishes in the first instance that the amount was paid otherwise than as legal remuneration. This contention is contrary to the clear terms of section 4(1) and would render illusory the presumption arising under the section.

anchor.surface_text: Section 4(1) of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947, provides to the extent material, that where in any trial of an offence punishable under section 161 of the Penal Code or under section 5(2) of the Act, it is proved that an accused person has accepted any gratification (other than legal remuneration), it shall be presumed unless the contrary is proved that he accepted that gratification as a motive or reward such as is mentioned in section 161, Penal Code. The motive or reward mentioned in section 161 is inter alia, for doing or forbearing to do any official act.
As the appellant has failed to discharge his burden, the order of companyviction and sentence must be companyfirmed.
